page.title: 10Flora in the Chew Magna Area
page.content: The Chew river meanders in the valley through hilly countryside.The local farms are mostly pastoral,reseeding and fertilisation eliminating all but the most common flowers-thistles, buttercups and dandelions. However the hedges,stone walls and deep lanes remain with many flowers,particularly in Spring.Celandines,violets,bluebells and primroses give way to cow parsley, chervil,pink and white campion,herb robert,foxgloves and vetches with blackthorn,hawthorn, guelder rose, wayfaring tree and clematis flowering above. Around the river and local reservoirs,some water meadows and rough pastures survive and marsh and early purple orchids,dyer's greenweed, cowslip,yellow flag,wild angelica, water dropwort and many ferns still are found.Dominant trees are alder,willows,oak ash and sycamore.
